etymologies: late Middle English: from medieval Latin graduat- ‘graduated’, from graduare ‘take a degree’, from Latin gradus ‘degree, step’

notes.text: The traditional use is “be graduated from”: she will be graduated from medical school in June. However, it is now more common to say “graduate from”: she will graduate from medical school in June. The use of graduate as a transitive verb, as in he graduated high school last week, is increasingly common, especially in speech, but is considered incorrect by most traditionalists

definitions: a person who has successfully completed a course of study or training, especially a person who has been awarded an undergraduate academic degree.
shortDefinitions: person with undergraduate or first academic degree

definitions: a person who has received a high school diploma

examples.text: she is 19, a graduate of Lincoln High

definitions: a graduated cup, tube, flask, or measuring glass, used especially by chemists and pharmacists.
shortDefinitions: graduated cup, tube, flask, or measuring glass

notes.text: The traditional use is “be graduated from”: she will be graduated from medical school in June. However, it is now more common to say “graduate from”: she will graduate from medical school in June. The use of graduate as a transitive verb, as in he graduated high school last week, is increasingly common, especially in speech, but is considered incorrect by most traditionalists

definitions: successfully complete an academic degree, course of training, or high school

examples.text: I graduated from West Point in 1965

definitions: confer a degree or other academic qualification on

examples.text: the school graduated more than one hundred arts majors in its first year

definitions: move up to (a more advanced level or position)

examples.text: he started with motorbikes but now he's graduated to his first car

shortDefinitions: move up to more advanced level etc.

definitions: arrange in a series or according to a scale

examples.text: the stones were graduated in height from the lowest near the entrance to the tallest opposite

shortDefinitions: arrange in series or according to scale

definitions: mark out (an instrument or container) in degrees or other proportionate divisions

examples.text: the stem was graduated with marks for each hour

shortDefinitions: mark out instrument etc. in gradations

definitions: change (something, typically color or shade) gradually or step by step

examples.text: the color is graduated from the middle of the frame to the top

notes.text: The traditional use is “be graduated from”: she will be graduated from medical school in June. However, it is now more common to say “graduate from”: she will graduate from medical school in June. The use of graduate as a transitive verb, as in he graduated high school last week, is increasingly common, especially in speech, but is considered incorrect by most traditionalists

definitions: having graduated from a school or academic program
shortDefinitions: having graduated from school or academic program
